title: Telegraph Wires
summary: The first global networks ran on copper telegraph wires, tapping out messages in Morse code.
facts: Undersea telegraph cables connected continents in the 1850s.
Morse code became a universal language for early networks.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='40' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2'/><text x='50' y='55' text-anchor='middle' fill='white' font-size='12'>Cu</text>

trivia.question: What was the primary material used in telegraph wires?
trivia.fact: Copper's excellent conductivity made it ideal for long-distance telegraph lines connecting continents!

trivia.question: What code was used to send messages via telegraph?
trivia.fact: Morse code revolutionized communication, allowing operators to tap out letters as dots and dashes.

title: Coaxial Boom
summary: Coaxial cables delivered early television and long-distance phone lines with shielding against noise.
facts: A central conductor and braided shield reduce interference.
Still used today in cable TV and RF links.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#c0c0c0'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='15' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2'/><text x='50' y='55' text-anchor='middle' fill='white' font-size='10'>Cu</text>

trivia.question: What does the 'coaxial' in coaxial cable mean?
trivia.fact: Coaxial means 'same axis' - the inner conductor shares the same center line as the outer shield!

title: Fiber Optic Revolution
summary: Light-speed networking! Glass strands carry terabits across cities and oceans with minimal loss.
facts: Total internal reflection guides light through the core.
Modern transoceanic cables are mostly fiber optic.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#ffffff'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#87ceeb'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#ffffff'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='15' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2'/><text x='50' y='55' text-anchor='middle' fill='black' font-size='10'>SiO2</text>

trivia.question: What principle allows light to travel through fiber optic cables?
trivia.fact: Total internal reflection bounces light rays inside the fiber, preventing signal loss over long distances!

title: Ethernet & Twisted Pair
summary: RJ45 connectors and twisted pairs power local networks from 10BASE-T to 10G and beyond.
keyAdvancement: Twisted pair for local area networks
facts: Power over Ethernet can deliver data and power together.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='10' y='30' width='80' height='40' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='30' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='70' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><text x='50' y='25' text-anchor='middle' fill='black' font-size='10'>Twisted Pair</text>

trivia.question: Why are pairs of wires twisted in Ethernet cables?
trivia.fact: Twisting cancels out electromagnetic interference, allowing clearer signals over longer distances!

title: HDMI, USB‑C & Beyond
summary: High-speed serial links carry video, power, and data through tiny reversible connectors.
facts: USB‑C supports up to 240W power delivery.
Alternate modes tunnel protocols like DisplayPort.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='20' y='40' width='60' height='20' fill='#000000'/><rect x='25' y='45' width='50' height='10' fill='#ffd700'/><text x='50' y='52' text-anchor='middle' fill='black' font-size='8'>Pins</text>

trivia.question: What makes USB-C connectors 'reversible'?
trivia.fact: USB-C's symmetrical shape means it plugs in correctly no matter which way you insert it!
